main-text.text: State Capitol P.O. Box 2062 Albany, NY 12220-0062 www.its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The purpose of this policy is to ensure that State agencies are properly using genderneutral terminology on their websites and online forms.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides the Office of Information Technology Services (ITS) with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 1 , issued January 2002, provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security and business re-engineering. Details regarding this authority can be found in NYS ITS Policy, NYS-P08-002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines .
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy applies to ITS, its employees and contractors, and ITS supported agencies ("Client Agency").
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103-B of the State Technology Law ("STL") requires that State agencies use "…gender neutral terminology on their websites…" unless "…such language is in reference to a specific person, or a specific group of people...in accordance with the gender identity of such person or group of people." Pursuant to Section 103(23) of the STL, ITS is required to issue guidance to State agencies for compliance with this law. In accordance with these requirements, ITS adopts the New York State Gender Inclusive Language Policy Guidance attached hereto as Appendix 1 as its guidance f or the use of gender-neutral terminology on State agency websites and online forms.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is required with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http://www.its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 7.0 Contact Information
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Submit all inquiries and requests for future enhancements to the policy owner at:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Division of Legal Affairs Reference: ITS-P24-005 NYS Office of Information Technology Services State Capitol, PO Box 2062
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Albany, NY 12220-0062
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Albany, NY 12220-0062
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: ITS policies, standards, and guidelines may be found on the Inside Edge at: https://nysemail.sharepoint.com/sites/myITS/InsideEdge/Pages/Policies.aspx
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 8.0 Revision History
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy document should be reviewed consistent with the requirements set forth in NYS-P08-002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: 9.0 Related Documents
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Page 3 of 8
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Appendix 1
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: New York State Gender Inclusive Language Policy Guidance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A. Overview
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This guidance is intended for State Entities as defined under Section B below. It provides instructions on how to draft formal documents without using unnecessary gender-specific language.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This guidance also provides specific instructions regarding State Entity implementation of A.1371-A/S.208-A of 2023, which requires agencies to use gender-neutral terminology on their websites.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: B. Gender Inclusive Language Policy
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Pursuant to A.1371-A/S.208-A of 2023, as amended by Chapter 21 of the Laws of New York of 2024, State Entities are required to avoid the use of gender-specific language - such as "he," "she," "his," and "her" - on all website content created on or after July 24, 2024. This applies to all website content, including forms accessible through the website, that is created by or on behalf of an agency, or is within an agency's control to modify. While this requirement applies only to website content create on or after July 24, 2024, agencies should also, wherever possible, make updates to older content as well.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: In addition to website content, State Entities should also avoid the use of genderspecific language and should adhere to these guidelines when drafting laws, proposed legislation, rules, regulations, reports, policies, and other formal documents.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: a. When conducting reviews of and making amendments to existing laws, legislation, rules, regulations, reports, policies, and other formal documents, State Entities should also, where possible, make updates to remove and replace any gender-specific language from the provision(s) being amended.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: b. If amending portions of existing law with gender-neutral terminology, State Entities should also review the entire section of law to ensure that changes are not creating confusion or conflict with other language within the section and should make additional conforming amendments as needed.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: c. For purposes of this policy, "State Entities" shall mean (i) all agencies and departments over which the Governor has
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Page 4 of 8
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: executive authority and as defined in subdivision 3, section 2a of the State Finance Law; and (ii) all public benefit corporations, public authorities, boards, and commissions f or which the Governor appoints the Chair, the Chief Executive, or at least 50% of the entity's board members, commissioners or comparable officers.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: C. Gender-Specific Nouns
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: (i) State Entities should avoid using nouns that are genderspecific, and should , where possible, use substitutes of the same meaning. See Section F for exceptions.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: a. Gender-specific nouns and possible substitutes include but are not limited to:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: b. For example:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "For the purpose of this section, the term FIRE FIGHTER fireman shall mean a member of a fire department whose duties include fire service..."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: (ii) Qualifiers may be added to gender-neutral nouns where lack of distinction may otherwise change the intent of the language or not properly capture the intended context.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: a. For example:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: "Proceedings to establish the paternity of a child may be instituted during the pregnancy of the mother GESTATIONAL PARENT or after the birth of the child… unless paternity has been acknowledged by the father NON-GESTATIONAL PARENT in writing or by furnishing support."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 5 of 8
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: D. Gender-Specific Pronouns
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: (i) State Entities should avoid using gender-specific pronouns wherever possible.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: a. Repeat the subject of the sentence or substitute a noun for the pronoun.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: (ii) Methodologies for drafting measures without the use of gender-specific pronouns include:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: i. Examples of noun substitutes include but are not limited to, the employee, the supervisor, the customer, the candidate, the interviewee, the commissioner, the officer, the member.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: ii. For example:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. Once she THE INDIVIDUAL submits an application, the agency has 30 days to respond.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 1. A person may be eligible for a waiver if he SUCH PERSON applies.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 3. Once a judge reviews a case, he SUCH JUDGE will issue a decision.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: b. Rewrite sentences to eliminate the pronoun or use an article such as "a," "an," "the," or "that" instead of the pronoun.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: i. For example:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. The individual must submit his THE application before 5pm on December 31.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 1. The employee holds his A position until notice of his resignation.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 3. A person who CARRIES has in his possession a weapon will not be allowed in the building.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 5. The applicant must pay the fee for him for THAT APPLICANT to be considered.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4. An officer may issue a license after DETERMINING he determines that the application meets the requirements.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: (iii) If State Entities make use of gender-neutral terminology such as pronouns "they/them/theirs," they should ensure that such terminology does not change the fundamental meaning or intent of the text. In cases where the use of "they/them/theirs" pronouns alters the meaning or intent of the text, Entities shall use the alternate
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Page 6 of 8
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Page 7 of 8
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: methodologies listed above instead.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: a. For example, in section 120.06 of the penal law:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: ii. In the above example, replacing the term "he" with "they" would cause confusion for both which and how many actors are involved in the elements of the crime.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: i. "A person is guilty of gang assault in the second degree when, with intent to cause physical injury to another person and when aided by two or more other persons actually present, he THAT PERSON causes serious physical injury to such person or to a third person."
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: E. Language inclusive of transgender, gender nonconforming, and nonbinary (TGNCNB+) individuals
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: (i) Language to refer to individuals of different genders continues to evolve. Currently, some terms include:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: b. Gender Expansive
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: a. Transgender
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: c. Gender Diverse
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: e. Non-binary
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: d. Gender Nonconforming
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: f. Genderfluid
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: i. A lactation room is available on the third floor for women PEOPLE who are breastfeeding OR CHESTFEEDING.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: (ii) If State Entities draft measures with specific reference to genderrelated concerns, it should utilize language that is inclusive of people of all genders, where applicable. a. For example:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: ii. A lactation room is available on the third floor for women PEOPLE WHO NEED IT.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: F. Gender-specific language in reference to a specific person or specific group of people
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: (i) State Entities may still use gender-specific language on website content or other relevant materials only if such language is in reference to a specific person or a specific group of people. In such circumstances, the gender-specific language used must be in accordance with the gender identity of the person or group of people being discussed.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: (ii) State Entities may still use gender-specific language when drafting
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: laws, proposed legislation, rules, regulations, reports, policies, and other formal documents if use of gender-neutral terminology would fundamentally alter the underlying policy or legislation. a. For example:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: ii. In the above example, references to gender specific language in "minority and women-owned business enterprises" would not be changed. However, the reference to "his or her" pronouns would be changed since it is limiting in scope.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: i. "Personal net worth includes the individual's share of assets held jointly with said individual's spouse and does not include the individual's ownership interest in the certified minority and womenowned business enterprise [NO CHANGE], the individual's equity in his or her THEIR primary residence, ownership…"
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: The above guidelines do not represent an exhaustive list of the circumstances when using gender inclusive language may be appropriate. When utilizing any of the recommendations included in this document, please contact the document owner listed in Section 7.0.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 8 of 8
